sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Here, take them; do what you will with them: I will be guided by you—Yet this affair, of Langwood's letter—

sp.speaker: Fam.
sp.p: Will make dreadful confuſion, my lord—Let me think, a little—I have it—Suppoſe we delay the delivery of it, for a few days; ſomething may happen, in that time, that may ſave the unhappy Harriet the pain of ſuch a diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Tho' I have little hopes, on that account, yet wou'd I not precipitate her wretchedneſs; it was to ſave her from it, Frampton, that firſt induced me—

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Talk nomore of it, my lord—Mr. Willis—

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: So, they are friends, again, I ſee. (Aſide.)—Did your honour call, Mr. Frampton?

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Take theſe letters, and give them to Sir William's ſervant, to be delivered, immediately.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: What, all of them, my lord?

sp.speaker: Framp.
sp.p: No, this one muſt be kept back. Look it up, carefully, 'till I call for it.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Come, my dear Frampton, I have a thouſand obligations to you, and a thouſand things to ſpeak to you, about.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p:
My dear Frampton!—There's a fellow for you, that, without half a crown in his pocket, talks as much ſtuff, about honour, and ſuch nonſenſe, as if he were a duke—They have not broke the ſeal, I find; that's Frampton's fault: if he had not return'd, the inſtant he did, I wou'd have ſatisfied my lord's curioſity, and my own—Well, cannot I do ſo, now? A good ſervant ſhou'd prevent his maſter's
wiſhes—My lord, I am ſure, would be glad to know the contents; egad, and ſo ſhould I, too—but how ſhall I come at 'em?—This curſed ſeal (flirts it with his finger.) Zounds! what have I done?—what an accident! why, the letter's open?—why, if it is, one may read it, without offence—So, by your leave, good Mrs. Winifred— (reads) Madam, as I am ſenſible the dreadful moment now approaches, when I muſt render an account of all my actions—A ſteward's account will be tolerably long, I ſuppoſe. (Continues reading.) I wiſh, even by this late confeſſion, to atone for the crime I have been guilty of, in aiding lord Euſtace to impoſe upon your niece, by a feigned marriage.—The devil! This is a confeſſion, indeed! for which, like all other mean-ſpirited, whimpering raſcals, he deſerves to be hanged. My lord was in the right, to look ſharp, after this buſineſs—We muſt have been blown up, if it had come to light. But as I hope to be well paid, for the contents of this, I may let the others go free.
sp.stage: SCENE changes to Sir William Evans's Apartment, HARRIET, ſeated on a Couch, leaning on her Arm.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
I cannot pierce thro' the myſtery, in which I am involved. I ſtrive, in vain, to recover my confidence in lord Euſtace. Theſe fatal reports unhinge my very ſoul—Yet nothing can abate my love. One falſe ſtep has involved me, in a thouſand difficulties. I can endure my ſituation, no longer; and let the conſequence be what it may, I will reveal the ſecret, to my father. But then, my lord's intreaties, and my aunt's commands—why even they muſt be ſacrificed, to filial duty—Wretch,
that I am, how did I dare to break that firſt of moral ties!—Heavens! he is here!
sp.stage: Enter Sir WILLIAM, with a Letter in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I have juſt received a letter, from your brother, Harriet, which I ſhould have had, ten days ago, had I been at home.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Does he aſſign a cauſe, for coming to London, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Yes, yes, 'tis as Loyd gueſſed, an affair of galantry, but an honourable buſineſs, tho'—I long 'till ye are both married, that I may hear no more of romances. I hope, when Harry has led the way, you will have no objection to follow him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What ſhall I ſay to him?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I wiſh I knew who my future daughter-in-law is to be. Harry tells me ſhe has a great fortune; but that, I ſuppoſe, is a ſweetener—But if ſhe has worth and virtue, ſufficient to make him happy, I ſhal • be content.—But what's the matter, Harriet? I thought your illneſs was quit gone off—you look as if you had been weeping—My ſiſter, I ſuppoſe—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, Sir; indeed her goodneſs to me, as well as yours, is graved upon my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: She is a very odd woman—She wou'd fain perſuade me, that I diſtreſſed you, by jeſting with captain Loyd, about lord Euſtace's miſtreſs—I begin to think that ſhe is in love with him, herſelf—Of what conſequence are his galantries to her? I dare ſay he has had a hundred, of the ſame ſort; and that the lady, to whom he is now going to offer his hand, can have but a very ſmall remnant, of his heart.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I have heard him ſay, Sir, they ſhould never be divided.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p:
Fine talking, for a libertine, truly!—However, I agree with you, that it is not right, to
make a jeſt, of thoſe unfortunate women he may have ruined—And I commend your delicacy, upon this occcaſion, as I well know it is the reſult of the moſt amiable female virtues, modeſty, and compaſſion.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: O, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What ails my child?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What is the matter? You amaze me, Harriet!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I am—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You ſee, before you, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Don't diſtract me! Whom do I ſee?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I am—lord Euſtace—my father!—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Speak; go on—Lord Euſtace!—What of him?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I am his wife—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What—lord Euſtace's wife!—Then you are a wretch, indeed!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Yet pardon me, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I cannot pardon you! Harriet, you have undone yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: O do not ſay ſo, Sir, when it is in your power, to make me happy.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I wou'd it were—but there is very little proſpect of happineſs, for a virtuous woman, who is connected with a libertine.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, you have miſtaken his character; and when you know him better, I am ſure you will be ſorry—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: It is you, child, that I fear will have cauſe to be ſorry, for having miſtaken his character—young women are but bad judges, of their lovers morals.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My aunt, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p:
Aye, aye, ſhe, I ſuppoſe, was privy to the match; he is a lord, and that's enough for her.
I might have expected ſuch a ſtroke, from her intolerable vanity—But how have I been deceived, in my opinion, both of your duty, and affection to me!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My future conduct, Sir, ſhall prove them both.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: O Harriet! What a diſappointment is mine? I hoped to have ſeen you united to a man of ſenſe, and worth, who wou'd have reſpected, as well as loved you—Inſtead of that, you are now joined to one, who, from his too intimate knowledge of the vicious part of your ſex, is likely to deſpiſe them all.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I flatter myſelf, Sir, that the goodneſs, both of his heart, and underſtanding, will make him readily renounce any light errors, he may have fallen into.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I wiſh it, moſt ſincerely—but—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Do not, Sir, injure him, by doubting it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I fear, my child, you flatter yourſelf, in vain, with any change in your huſband's conduct—that laſt amour, which captain Loyd ſpoke of—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How bleſt am I, to be able to acquit my lord!—Tho' bluſhing I avow it, it was his myſterious attachment to his wife, that caus'd that vile report.—O Sir! let me, again, upon my knees, entreat you to pardon what is paſt, and give lord Euſtace leave to prove the ſincerity of his affection, to me, by his reſpectful tenderneſs and gratitude, toward you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Riſe, riſe, my Harriet. Since it is ſo—I forgive, and bleſs you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You have made your daughter happy—how will lord Euſtace be tranſported!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Wou'd I cou'd ſee occaſion, for this joy! (Aſide.)—Retire, my child; compoſe your ſpirits, and let me compoſe mine.—I wiſh to be alone.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: It is almoſt impoſſible, Sir!—I am too, too happy.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Why was this marriage huddled in the dark? It ſhall not be kept ſecret—Myſtery is the fit maſk for vice; my daughter needs it not—I am impatient, 'till I ſee lord Euſtace.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: It is not long, Sir, ſince he went from hence.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: No matter; leave me, Robert.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: If your honour wou'd hear a few words, that I have to ſay.—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I cannot hear you, now; my thoughts are all engaged. (To himſelf.)—I muſt write to colonel Loyd, directly.—I ſhall have a ſad piece of work, with the old gentleman at Trevallin—he doats upon my girl, as if ſhe were his child.—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, and ſo does every one, who knows her, except ſome of the folk in this houſe.—I wiſh, indeed I do, that we were fairly out of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Well, we ſhall leave it, ſoon—but, for the preſent, Robert—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Your honour little knows what's going forward, in it—ſuch quarrelling, ſuch high words! aye, and ſuch fine words, too, as I ne'er heard, before; tho', if I underſtand them right, they have but a black meaning.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Robert, we'll talk of this, ſome other time.—I ſay, again, I am not at leiſure, now.—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
I can't be eaſy, 'till I tell you, Sir; as I am ſadly afraid there is ſomething a plotting, againſt your honour, or my young miſtreſs.—I have heard that wicked Willis talking of her, to his fellow ſervant.—O Sir, that fellow knows all his lord's ſecrets; he is at the beginning, and ending, of all miſchief; and he ſays, as how Miſs Harriet has been only impos'd upon. (Sir Wm. ſtarts.)—Yes, Sir, impos'd upon—
and that his maſter will be married to a fine lady, in leſs than a month's time.—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: How! impos'd upon! what can this mean? lord Euſtace dare not think of any thing ſo baſe.—I injure both myſelf and him, by the ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: All I know of the matter, is, Sir, that the gentleman that lives here (whom I believe to be a very honeſt man, tho' Willis calls him a poor rogue) and my lord Euſtace, had a ſad quarrel, and they talked ſo loud, that I cou'd not help overhearing Mr. Frampton—for I ſcorn to liſten—reproaching my lord, with having behaved, very ill, both to you, and your daughter—but they were friends, afterwards, and went out, together.—But Willis ſaid a great deal more, to James, my lord's footman, to the ſame ſenſe—and whatever miſchief there is a brewing, I am ſure he knows all about it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I cannot comprehend the meaning of all this.—Impoſed upon!—I will be ſatisfied—His ſcoundrel ſervant talk of my daughter, and of his marriage with another lady!—I have not patience to wait the meeting with lord Euſtace—Is that fellow in the houſe?—That Willis, Robert?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, James and he have been taking a hearty glaſs, I believe; he looks pure and merry.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Bid him come to me, directly.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I am afraid he will be too cunning, for your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Do, as I bid you.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir. Wm.
sp.p: The happineſs, or miſery, of my child, ſeem now ſuſpended, in an equal balance.—Let my impatience to turn the ſcale in her favour, excuſe me, to myſelf, for condeſcending to inquire into another's ſecrets, tho' they ſo nearly concern me.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Your valet de chambre told me, Sir, that you deſired to ſpeak with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Our converſation will be but ſhort, Mr. Willis.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: I am in a rare humour, to bam this Welſh Baronet.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I ſay our converſation will be but ſhort, Mr. Willis; but I ſhou'd wiſh it to be ſincere.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: There he has hit the mark. (Aſide.)—O, to be ſure, Sir! I have been remarkable, for truth and ſincerity, all my life, Sir. My mother taught me, from a child, never to tell a lie.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Truth is, certainly, the foundation of every other virtue, and I hope I may depend upon yours, to anſwer a few queſtions, that I ſhall aſk you.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: O yes, you may depend upon me.—What the devil is he about! He is certainly going to hear me my catechiſm.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I ſhall think myſelf obliged to you, if you will acquaint me with what you know, in relation to lord Euſtace's marriage.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Me, Sir! How is it poſſible I can tell?—All's out, I ſuppoſe—O that curſed Langwood!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: No trifling with me, friend; I will be anſwer'd.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Yes, to be ſure, Sir, all ſervants ought to give civil anſwers to gentlemen; but really, Sir, I cannot poſſibly tell you any thing about it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Since fair means will not prevail upon you, this ſhall extort the truth.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p:
For heaven's ſake, Sir, don't terrify an evidence, in this land of liberty——You will either frighten what I do know, out of my head, or make
me confeſs any thing, without knowing any thing, at all, of the matter.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: No prevarication, Sir—Men, like you, who are bred up in vice and idleneſs, are to be influenced by nothing, but their fears—Therefore, tell me, I ſay, again, what you know of this marriage?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Yes, yes, they have had another letter, from Langwood; ſo I may as well make a merit of giving up ours, ſince there can be none in keeping it from him.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What are you muttering, villain? Don't urge me farther; I have loſt my reaſon, and will not anſwer for the conſequences.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: I will do any thing, Sir, if you will be pleaſed to drop the point of that ugly piece of cold iron.—What you have heard from Langwood, is moſt certainly true.—But a good ſervant, you know, Sir, ought to keep his maſter's ſecrets, till his life is in danger.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Langwood!—Maſter's ſecrets!—Explain yourſelf, this moment.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Dear Sir, be patient—What need you have the trouble of hearing it over again, when you know it all, already?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Dare you again inſult me, with your trifling?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Why, really, Sir, I can't ſay it was a right thing of my lord, but none of his ſervants were in fault, except Langwood; we muſt do what our maſters bid us; and he, poor devil, is ſorry enough, as you know, Sir, and may ſee, Sir.
sp.stage: (Takes the letter out of his pocket, Sir William ſnatches it.)

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Langwood, again!—Who is Langwood? And what has he to do, with your lord's marriage? And what is this letter?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: It is for Mrs. Winifred, Sir; and as to Langwood, he was the mock-doctor, the counterfeit parſon, that married my lord; I was only the clerk, indeed, Sir; and I hope your honour will be ſo good to forgive me, and not leave all the ſin, and the ſhame, too, upon my poor conſcience.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Why, villain! raſcal! what is all this ſtuff? If your lord be married to my daughter, how dare he think of any other wife?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: So, I have made a fine piece of work on't!—I find he did not know it was a ſham marriage, till now.— (Aſide.) Why, really, Sir, you terrify me ſo, that I don't rightly underſtand you; I thought you knew all about it, before I opened my lips to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I aſked you, wretch, about your lord's intended marriage?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: O lord, Sir, it was very unlucky I did not underſtand you. I ſhall be obliged to fly my country; my lord will never let me live in England, after this. I ſhall loſe an excellent place, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Be gone, thou profligate! Fly from my ſight, this moment.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I am an undone ſcoundrel, that's the truth of it!—But this comes of muddling, in a morning—Had I been ſober, I ſhou'd have been an over-match, for his worſhip, or any juſtice of peace, in England. I'll e'en retire, till my maſter, and this Welch family, have ſo reconciled matters, between themſelves, that a gentleman may be able to live, with ſome ſatisfaction, amongſt them.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What am I now to think! My child is diſhonoured! Let me contain my rage, a moment longer, and be yet more fully ſatisfied, from their own lips.—Robert!
Go, call my ſiſter, and—I cannot name her.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Miſs Harriet, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Aye, bid them come hither.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I never ſaw my maſter ſo diſturbed, before.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Of what can they inform me? Do I not know my daughter is undone?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Pray, my lady, go firſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Where are theſe wretched, theſe unhappy women, that have brought ſhame, and ſorrow, on themſelves, and infamy on me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Hey day! What's the matter now? Harriet told me ſhe had juſt leſt you in a heavenly temper; what can have happened, to diſcompoſe you, ſince? but Much Ado about Nothing, is your play, from morning, 'till night.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Read that—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: A broken ſeal! What can be the contents?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Dear Sir, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Do not talk to me, unhappy girl! Lord Euſtace has deceived you—you are not his wife.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: All gracious heaven!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Rage and madneſs! O women, women, what have ye done!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Vaſtly well, I think.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Do not provoke me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p:
You are enough to provoke a ſaint, yourſelf.—What is all this ſtuff, this letter, this forgery, this nonſenſe! He perſonate a parſon! I
think I ſhou'd know a clergyman, in any dreſs. I am not quite ſo eaſily impos'd upon, as you, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I will not anſwer you—But thou, undutiful, unhappy girl! what can'ſt thou ſay?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I wiſh you wou'd hear reaſon, and ſpare your reproaches, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No—give them vent—I only fear to live, not die—Let looſe your rage, upon me: I implore it; I will endure it all.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: You have deſerved it. Your own deceit has fallen upon your head; you are betray'd, diſhonour'd, and abandon'd, both by your villain huſband, and your wretched father.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: O Sir! have pity on my anguiſh and deſpair!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I cannot bear your ſight—My being, life itſelf, is hateful to me.— (To Mrs. Win.) This is your pride, your rage for quality!—You have undone my child, and I renounce you both!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Will you forſake me, alſo?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Forſake you! no, child; this is a perfect chimera of your father's.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: O let us go this moment, implore his goodneſs to forgive our fault, and fly, for ever, from this hateful dwelling.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: By no means; I don't approve of your quitting your huſband's houſe. I wou'd have you write to him, immediately, and deſire him to come to us, this evening.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I write to him! You make me ſhudder, at the thought.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: It muſt be done, child—I inſiſt upon it—This is ſome trick, meant to impoſe upon us.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I feel the impoſition, here—Lord Euſtace has betrayed us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I tell you, Harriet, it is impoſſible—he is at leaſt the ninth peer of his family, in a direct line.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Tho' honours may be—honour is not hereditary, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: No matter; write to him, I ſay: you are, and muſt be lady Euſtace, at any rate, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And can you think me vile enough, after ſuch perfidy, to receive his hand? Can I vow to honour the man, whom I no longer eſteem? Shall I go to the altar with him, and ſwear to be faithful, to a perjur'd wretch? again repeat my vows of everlaſting love, for him who has abandoned, and undone me? No; I would ſooner die, a thouſand, thouſand deaths.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: You are juſt as obſtinate, as your father—Now you have taken this into your head, nothing can get it out again.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Do you think my father could be ſo inhuman, without juſt grounds, to ſtab me to the heart? It is, it is too true!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I will not believe a word of it.—I never was miſtaken, in my life; my brother is ever in the wrong.—I deſire, Harriet, you will write to lord Euſtace, directly.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Indeed, I will not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Then, poſitively, I will—I am determin'd to know the truth, from him. I own I begin to be a little doubtful, about this matter, myſelf. This letter may be forg'd—but thoſe eternal reports confound me—'Tis impoſſible he ſhould dare to deceive me—but if he has, he ſhall find that the Ap Evans's are not to be injured, with impunity.

div.head: ACT IV.
div.stage: Enter Capt. LOYD, and Col. EVANS.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: MY father in London! you ſurprize me, captain—What can have brought him here?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Nay, as to the matter of ſurprize, my young hero, your father was quite as much aſtoniſh'd, at hearing of your being in the ſame port, as you can be; and as to your aunt Winifred, ſhe ſtarted, with as much amazement, as the ſailors that ſpied the firſt Patagonian. Your ſiſter, indeed, ſeem'd more pleas'd, than any of them, at the news, and inquir'd whether I had met you in healthy condition, and if I knew your moorings.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My gentle Harriet!—I am impatient to ſee her.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hoiſt ſail, and away, then; I'll be your convoy, tho' I ſhould like better to drop anchor, and take in refreſhment, for an hour or ſo, at the Admiralty Coffee-houſe, where I have appointed captain Blaſt, of the Boreas, and ſome other jolly lads, to meet me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am much obliged to you, captain, but will, by no means, ſuffer you to break your engagement.—I have a little buſineſs to diſpatch, before I can ſee my father, and ſhall eaſily find out the houſe, without troubling you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Why, that you may readily do, as it is inclos'd by a very high wall, and has a large handſome gate-way, with a bell at the door.—Aye,
aye, that bell was not plac'd there, to call the crew to prayers, but to prevent the neighbours from knowing who comes in and out, as they might do, if there was a rapper only.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I can't ſee why that caution ſhould be neceſſary.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: It is of no great uſe, at preſent—But time has been—Harkee me, Harry, there is a deviliſh ſtorm brewing over your head; you may look for dirty weather, I can tell you—Your father is in a confounded paſſion, at your having quitted the regiment, and is ſtrongly perſuaded that you'll ſpring a leak, my boy.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I wrote to my father, ſome time ago, to acquaint him with my motives; I have alſo written to my colonel, to account for my conduct.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Never fear, I'll take care of you, as I am ſure you did not deſert, from cowardice—But it was a ſilly trick, Harry.—Some girl, I ſuppoſe, is in the wind; they make fools of the wiſeſt of us.—I remember, when I was ſtation'd at Gibraltar, a Donna Iſabella—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Wou'd you were there, now: I know not how to get rid of this tireſome man.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A Spaniard, you may gueſs, by the name, had a deviliſh mind to come off with me, as ſhe ſaid, to ſee foreign parts—But I weigh'd anchor, ſlily, one moon-light night, and left the poor ſigniora on ſhore—But all men have not the gift of diſcretion: tho' I was a younker, then, Harry, not much turn'd of thirty, I'll aſſure you—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I think it was rather cruel in you, to forſake the lady, captain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Why, I did hear, afterwards, that there was a ballad made about it, intitled The Cruel Captain's Garland, and ſet to a very woeful tune—I
laugh at theſe things, Harry; but I find you are a truer lover, and have come here, in ſpite of wind and tide, in purſuit of your miſtreſs—You can't expect, however, that Sir William will be highly delighted, if you ſhou'd happen to make a loſing voyage of it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, it will be the moſt proſperous one of my life, and I ſhall be able to give my father a ſatisfactory account, of my conduct.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why, if your miſtreſs be well freighted, a ſixty thouſand pounder, or ſo, he will have no objection, I ſuppoſe.—But come, my boy, tell me a little about it: is ſhe maid, or widow, Harry? I like to hear love-ſtories, mightily.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: She is a maiden, young, and beautiful, and of a rank and fortune, beyond my expectation, captain. We have lov'd one another, long; her guardians are upon the point of diſpoſing of her, to another; ſhe has deſir'd me to free her from their tyranny, and accept of her hand, as my reward—Glorious recompence!—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why, Harry! this is running before the wind, with a vengeance—Not ſo faſt, not ſo faſt, my boy, you go at the rate of twelve knots, an hour—This ſtory ſounds a little romantic, tho', and puts me in mind of the lady, that the flying man comes to ſave from the monſter.—But 'tis odd enough, that I ſhou'd not know this lady; prithee, Harry, what's her name?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You muſt excuſe my not anſwering that queſtion, captain, as you might poſſibly become my rival.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Why, to be ſure, if ſhe had applied to me, ſhe ſhou'd have been far enough from her guardians, by this, we'd have run gunnel to, all the way, my
boy, and left them, and you on the dry land, Harry.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I ſhall tell her of your intended galantry, captain; and I hope you and ſhe will be better acquainted—for the preſent, I muſt wiſh you a good evening.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Nay, if you have a mind to ſheer off, colonel, I wiſh you a fair gale.—I never grapple with any thing, but a pretty laſs, or an enemy; and ſo, your ſervant, your ſervant, colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My meeting with this blundering ſailor, was unlucky, as my father may, perhaps, be diſpleas'd at my not waiting on him, the moment I knew of his being in London.—But I cannot break my engagement, with lady Anne—every thing muſt give way, to that charming woman—I will fly to her, directly, and, if poſſible, find time to pay my duty to my father, before I ſleep.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: He will come, then; you have ſtaid a great while, Robert.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: My lord was not at home, madam; and as you deſir'd I ſhou'd bring an anſwer, I was oblig'd to wait his coming—Every thing ſeems in confuſion, in the family; his lordſhip, it ſeems, is to be married, in a few days; they are all packing up, and the ſervants ſcarce knew where to find pen, ink, and paper.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p:
This ſtartles me—'Tis but too plain I have been deceived. (Aſide.)—Hearken to me, Robert, and do, exactly, what I command you—go
and place yourſelf by the private door, in the garden, and the moment you hear a key turn in the lock, come and tell me.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I ſhall obey you, madam.—I am ſure all is not right. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I muſt, if poſſible, prevent Sir William's knowing of this interview—But here he comes—
—I hope you have vented all your rage, brother, and that one may talk, a little calmly, to you, now?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: O yes! I have great reaſon to be calm.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I can tell you that a little more of your outrageous fury, wou'd have kill'd your daughter; nor do I know what fatal effect it might have had, upon my own conſtitution.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: That is not very eaſily ſhock'd, I believe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: That is more than you know, at leaſt, brother; but a perſon ſo intirely given up to their paſſions, never once reflects upon conſequences.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I wiſh you had reflected upon conſequences; but thoſe who have err'd themſelves, are ever ready to reflect on others.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: A truce with reflections, on all ſides; and in caſe that there ſhou'd be any truth, in this infamous ſtory, let us ſet about forming ſome ſcheme, for redreſſing the affront, that he has dar'd offer to our family.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I ſhall not ſtand in need of your aſſiſtance. I am determin'd how to act.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Pray, Sir William, do not be headſtrong, but, for once, be adviſed by me.—I have thought of a ſcheme, and I am ſure it will anſwer.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: It is happy for my family, that I have a little ſenſe, brother, tho' I do not boaſt of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Your wiſdom in this matter, has been conſpicuous; but what new proofs of it, are we to expect, at preſent?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Suppoſe we were to ſend for lord Euſtace, and try what effect Harriet's tears, and my reproaches, wou'd have upon him—He has always had the greateſt deference, for my opinion.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Your opinion!—Is this your boaſted ſcheme?—He will not come; baſe as he is, it is impoſſible he cou'd endure her ſight.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Your affected ſagacity is enough to ſet one mad—You are miſtaken, as you always are.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I know it cannot be; the conſciouſneſs of his vile treachery, will keep him far from hence.—He dare not ſee her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I cannot bear this contradiction. (Aſide.)—For once let conviction conquer your obſtinacy: I wrote to him, myſelf, in Harriet's name; I have had his anſwer; he will be here, this night.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: And ſhall my daughter ſue to him, for juſtice? implore him to receive the hand he has rejected, and the heart he has betray'd? Shall ſhe be ſacrific'd, to make his peace? I tell you, no—I will have other vengeance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I ſee theſe horrid punctilios will ruin all—If we can make up this matter quietly, what does it ſignify, whether he be a man of honor, or no?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I never • uſt forget, that I am one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I wiſh you wou'd have a little patience, and hear me out—If this ſhould fail, I have another project, in my head, which I am certain muſt ſucceed—My imagination has not been idle, and I think it full as active, as your own.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I believe it may be rather more ſo—But I have no leiſure, for imaginary matters, now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Pray, Sir William, don't be ſo poſitive—you know lord Euſtace has a place, at court.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I wou'd, at leaſt, let the king know what a ſervant he has about him; and as I may reaſonably ſuppoſe that his majeſty may have heard of our anceſtors, tho' he knows nothing of you, Sir William, I wou'd adviſe you to throw yourſelf, at his feet—He is himſelf a father.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Bleſt may he long be, in that honour'd title! tho' I am render'd wretched, by the name—But what can he do, for me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Diſgrace, and diſplace the man, who has wrong'd you, altho' he be a lord.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What is his title? has he not debas'd it—But know, there is no difference of rank, before the throne—degrees of elevation, are only ſeen by thoſe, who look above them: kings muſt look down, and therefore ſee all equal; and in our monarch's ſight, the rights, even of the meaneſt ſubject, are precious as his own—But yet he cannot heal my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Tho' I can never believe that a knight baronet is upon a par, with a lord, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Abſurd diſtinctions! I will hear no more—The man who has the means of juſtice, in his own hands, and ſeeks for it elſewhere, deſerves to be the ſport of chance, and dupe of his own weakneſs—Then let him come, this night—I'll meet him as I ought.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p:
You are exactly in the ſame caſe, of the Diſſidents, at Warſaw; nothing, but force of arms, will content you; and like them, too, you may be
undone, by it—Suppoſe you were to meet lord Euſtace, and he ſhou'd kill you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I ſhall not, then, out-live my honor.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: This ſelf-will'd man diſtreſſes me, extremely—he is, for ever, diſconcerting my ſchemes—There never was ſuch a race of ideots, as the family of the Ap Evans's, myſelf excepted—there is not a head, in this houſe, but my own—To be ſure I have been a little over-reach'd, in this affair of the wedding; but the greateſt politicians are liable to miſtakes—I hope to repair all, yet, and make my niece a woman of quality, one way, or another.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Madam, I have juſt now heard the private door of the garden, unlock, and ran to tell you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Vaniſh! (Exit Rob.) I muſt not let my brother and lord Euſtace meet, 'till every thing is ſettled.
sp.stage: Enter Lord EUSTACE and Col. EVANS, with their Swords in their Hands, Lord EUSTACE lays his on a Chair.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: You are here in ſafety, Sir, and may put up your ſword; this houſe is mine, notwithſtanding the myſterious manner of my entrance—I hope you are not wounded?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Thanks to your courage, and generoſity, Sir, I have eſcaped unhurt. I thought our police was better conducted, than to ſuffer our lives to be endangered, by footpads.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Theſe accidents are leſs frequent, in this country, than they uſed to be; but no code of laws was ever yet framed, that cou'd make all men honeſt.—I am extremely happy, at having come ſo opportunely, to your aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I ſhall ever be grateful, for the obligation, Sir; but may I not know to whom I am obliged?

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Do not mention the matter as a favour, I intreat you—You wou'd, doubtleſs, have done the ſame for me; and had I happen'd to have come firſt, I ſhou'd have ſtood in need of your aſſiſtance—I am call'd lord Euſtace.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I ſhall remain indebted to your lordſhip, and wiſh you a good night.—What a rencontre!

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: I could wiſh you not to leave me, Sir; 'tis late, and therefore unſafe for either of us, to return alone—The fellows who attacked you, may lye in wait for you—I ſhall not ſtay here a quarter of an hour; and as I wiſh to be better acquainted with you, I ſhou'd be glad to know your addreſs.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am extremely obliged to your lordſhip. I am call'd colonel Weſton; you'll hear of me, at the hotel in Pall-mall.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Let me entreat you not to leave me—I am, at preſent, in a very difficult, and diſagreeable ſituation.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your lordſhip has a right to command me; but I hope you will not ſtay longer than the time you have mention'd, as I have ſome buſineſs to tranſact, this night.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: If that be the caſe, I will not treſpaſs upon you; perhaps, there may be ſomething ſimilar, in our circumſtances; for your buſineſs, at this hour, muſt, in all probability, be with a lady, and you may reaſonably ſuppoſe, by my being alone, and on foot, that I am come to meet one, here.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Let me entreat your lordſhip not to loſe ſuch precious minutes, but fly to the expecting fair one.—This is an odd diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: The matter is not as you imagine, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: There is, perhaps, a jealous huſband, or an old croſs father, my lord—

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Neither, colonel. But matches, made for intereſt, only, too often break the moſt delightful ties, the union of fond hearts—The lady, who lives here, is the moſt amiable of her ſex, and I adore her; yet, am on the point of marrying one, whom I can never love.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: This is a ſad affair, indeed, my lord.—I cou'd ſave you a great deal of trouble, if I were at liberty to tell you lady Anne's intentions.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: I fear the unhappy girl has heard of my intended marriage, as ſhe has written to me to come here, this night—I never was ſo embarras'd, or diſtreſs'd.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Some girl you keep, I preſume, my lord.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: By no means; ſhe is a woman of family and character—I am almoſt diſtracted about her—I will now ſtep and ſee if the coaſt be clear, as there are ſome of the family, that I ſhou'd not chuſe to encounter, at this late hour, and return to you, Sir, inſtantly—You ſee what confidence you have already inſpired me with.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
A confidence, indeed! but of what uſe can it be to me, who am bound in honor, not to betray it? (Looks at his watch.) Bleſs me, it is now paſt eleven—the time I ſpent with lady Anne, ſtole unperceived away. It will certainly be too late, to go to my father's, to-night; I muſt defer my viſit, 'till to-morrow; and as lord Euſtace don't ſeem in a great hurry to be married, I ſhall have time enough to get lady Anne out of her guardian's power, and
prepare my father for her reception—But here comes my new friend.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: All is quiet; I muſt therefore, take the opportunity of conveying you ſafe out, again; and I hope to have the pleaſure of being better known to you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your lordſhip's inclination does me honor.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Your obſtinacy is enough to diſtract me—I ſay you ſhall ſee him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Support me, gracious Heav'n!

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: My deareſt Harriet, your billet has alarm'd me, more than I can expreſs—I have made the utmoſt diſpatch that was poſſible, to fly to you; and the moments that have paſſed, ſince I received your commands, have been the moſt painful of my life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Your lordſhip need not enter into a defence of your punctuality.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Why is my Harriet's brow overcaſt? and her eyes quenched in tears? Why is ſhe ſilent?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Aſk your own heart!

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Is it poſſible that the idle report of my marriage, can have diſtreſs'd her, thus?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Horrid diſſembler!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Do not exhauſt your ſpirits, my dear Harriet; give me leave to talk to him (Aſide to Harriet.)—So then, my lord, what we have heard upon the ſubject, is but an idle report, without the leaſt foundation?

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: If you will but recollect, what has paſs'd between your niece and me, madam, you muſt be fully convinced it can be nothing more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: And yet, my lord, you ſeem, confuſed.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Why really, madam, the doubts you ſeem to entertain of my veracity, are a little diſtreſſing—But let me hope my Harriet will believe me, while I ſwear—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Away, my lord! I can believe no more—Cou'd I have thought that either my wrongs, or my reſentment, were capable of increaſe!

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Really, madam, I do not clearly underſtand the meaning of this converſation—and I muſt ſay, I think it rather ſevere, to be condemn'd, unheard.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I can contain my rage, no longer; read that.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Langwood's letter! All is diſcover'd, then!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I perceive that even a man of quality, may be diſconcerted—Your lordſhip did not uſe to be at a loſs, for an anſwer.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Have patience, madam; I confeſs that appearances are againſt me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Aye, and realities, too, my lord.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p:
I do not mean to juſtify myſelf—No, I plead guilty. The fear of loſing you, my Harriet, whom I lov'd more than life, and the apprehenſion of diſobliging my father, tempted me to
make you mine, in an illegal manner—But here I ſwear, I will repair the injury.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I think it will do; matters are in a right train, now, if I can but prevent Sir William from interrupting them.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: You are offended, Harriet, and have cauſe—but let not your reſentment turn againſt yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Cou'd I forgive myſelf, my lord, I then might pardon you; but while I think my puniſhment ſevere, I own I have deſerved it.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: You judge yourſelf, too hardly—Has either your virtue, or your delicacy, ſuffered, by my crime? Nay, even your reputation is ſtill free from ſtain; and if you will now condeſcend to accept my hand, my future life ſhall be devoted to your happineſs.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And can you think I'll be again deceived?

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: By heaven, you ſhall not!—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Nay, I will not—Your poor evaſions have no weight with me—Leave me, for ever leave me—I will not be united to you, by any ties.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Yet hear me, Harriet.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Wou'd I had never heard you—But tho' I were to liſten to you, now, you cannot ſhake my purpoſe. No—I can die!—

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: No, live, my Harriet! Live, to make me happy—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Where is he? I muſt, and will, ſee him.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Ah! Sir William! This is unlucky! I am not prepar'd, for this encounter

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What! is it poſſible that you ſhou'd dare to enter underneath this roof?

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: What ſhou'd I fear, Sir William?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Your own baſe heart, and my much injur'd honour; which calls upon you, now, for juſtice.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: So then, I find the pride of injur'd virtue, was aſſumed—Your daughter would ſecure me, by compulſion—But I deſpiſe aſſaſſins!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Do not, my lord, inſult my patience, farther; I did not know you were without a ſword: on that account, I put up mine; but know, young man, I ſhall not reſt, till it has done me juſtice.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Sir William, tho' I cannot pretend to juſtify the injuries I have done your daughter, I neither muſt, nor will be compell'd, to make the reparation; I ſhou'd, indeed, be unworthy to become her huſband, if fear cou'd make me ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: At the firſt hour you ſaw her, Sir, I ſhou'd have deemed you ſo—'Tis not your birth, young man, can varniſh over vices, ſuch as yours—Your rank renders them the more obnoxious.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: I readily allow myſelf to blame, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: You cannot then be baſe enough, to refuſe the ſole atonement, which is now within your power—

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: I will confeſs I felt my heart fubdued, by Harriet's grief, and tenderneſs—they had more power, than armies—She might have triumphed over me, but—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: You ſurely do not think I mean to give my daughter to you! What! to reward your vices, with a heart like hers—to have my child become, a ſecond time, a ſacriſice to that vain idol, Title!—No, Sir, it is another kind of reparation, I demand; and I will have it.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p:
A brave man, Sir William, never thinks meanly, of another's courage; and as I know you to
be ſo, I hope you will not think me otherwiſe, if I decline your offer.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: On what pretence, my lord? Have you not wrong'd me?

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: For that reaſon, only, I cannot, dare not, draw my ſword againſt you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Theſe are new rules of honour, form'd on the principles of fear, my lord.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Fear, Sir William!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Yes, my lord, I ſay it; none but a coward, ever will decline to meet the man he has injured; and ſhou'd you ſtill perſiſt in your refuſal, I will proclaim you one.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: This is too much—But conſider, Sir, you are—my Harriet's father.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: That conſideration wou'd brace a nerveleſs arm—But, look upon me, Sir; I am not bent beneath the weight of years—my mind and body both, are firm as yours; and the firſt ſhock that ever reach'd my heart, except her mother's loſs, is the diſgrace you have brought upon my child—The ſtain muſt be effac'd, my lord.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: I know not how to act; ſhou'd I declare my intention to marry Harriet, he wou'd deſpiſe me; and if I fight him, that renders it impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Come, come, my lord, this is no time for muſing—You muſt determine, inſtantly, to give me the ſatisfaction I require, or ſee your title poſted up, with the honourable addition, of coward, to it.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Nay, then, Sir William, tho' with reluctance, I muſt accept your offer—Name your time, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: At eight, to-morrow morning—

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p:
I'll call upon you, Sir, and bring a friend—But let me once more add, that you are the
only man, on earth, that I ſhou'd fear to meet, upon ſuch terms▪

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I am glad my ſon is ignorant, of this affair—Had he been here, he muſt have fought lord Euſtace—He has, I hope, a long, and happy life, before him; mine, tho' not quite worn out, is of leſs value; and if I loſe it, in defence of my child's honour, 'tis well diſpoſed of.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: So ſhe was, or might have been, very well diſpos'd of, but for your intemperance—You have managed your matters, very cleverly, to be ſure—You have driven lord Euſtace away, and the family of the Ap Evans's are diſgrac'd for ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Thou weak, vain, woman! whoſe folly has undone me, and my child.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Not I truly, Sir William—It is her own high-flown principles, that have ruined her—My lord offered to marry her, over and over again, it ſeems, but ſhe with her nonſenſical, romantical notions, affected to deſpiſe him, and refuſed to be his wife, on any terms.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Has ſhe? I rejoice, to hear it—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Rejoice; at what! at her being a mad woman? I think, in her ſituation, ſhe needed not have been ſo nice—It would have been much better for her, to have been lady Euſtace, even againſt his will, than Miſs Harriet Evans's, againſt her own.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: How nearly pride, and meanneſs, are allied! You wou'd obtrude your niece, upon a man, who has abandoned, and diſhonour'd her; then vainly think ſhe might receive diſtinction, from a title, which force, not choice, beſtowed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p:
Brother, I neither underſtand logic, nor ſophiſtry, but I am very ſorry matters are as they are.
—As to Harriet, I believe it will be of no great conſequence, to her; ſhe will ſoon break her heart, I imagine—But the ſcandal of this affair, will reſt upon the ſurvivors.—I don't think I ſhall ever be able to ſhew my face, at Monmouth, again.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Away! The moments now are too precious, to be waſted. Where is Harriet?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: In her chamber, like a diſtracted wretch, tearing herſelf to pieces. I endeavoured to comfort her, as much as I could, by telling her how wrong ſhe had acted, and that ſhe might have lived to be a counteſs, if he had followed my advice.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Was this the conſolation you offer'd to her grief? How cou'd you be ſo barbarous? The proper ſpirit ſhe has ſhewn, in refuſing that worthleſs lord, has replaced her in my heart—I will go try to comfort her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Aye, ſo you may; you are the fitteſt to go together. For my part, I diſclaim the miſmanagment of this whole affair; and remember, I'll no longer be accountable, for meaſures, that I am not ſuffer'd to guide.

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: Ld EUSTACE and Mr. FRAMPTON diſcovered.
Lord Euſtace riſes from a Table, as if writing.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: YOUR meeting with Sir William, was extremely unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: I moſt ſincerely wiſh we had not met; but that is paſt—

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Then I ſuppoſe you think the worſt is over.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: No, Frampton, 'tis to come.—Sir William has inſiſted upon my meeting him, this morning.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Impoſſible, my lord! you muſt not fight him. Think on the conſequences: if you ſhould be ſo unhappy, as to kill the father of the woman you have highly injured, the world wou'd certainly unite againſt you, and drive you from ſociety.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: In that caſe, I ſhou'd be but ill qualified, for ſolitude, I confeſs.—Now, my dear Frampton, as I know you are my friend, and as I wou'd not wiſh any other perſon ſhou'd be acquainted with this ſtory, I muſt deſire you will be my ſecond.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p:
It is much beneath a man of honour, to make profeſſions, either of his friendſhip, or his courage; but, on this occaſion, I muſt tell you, that I wou'd hazard my life, for your ſervice, in any other cauſe; but I will not be concern'd, in this
infamous affair; and, I ſay, again, you muſt not raiſe your arm, againſt Sir William.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: You do not know how I am circumſtanced. He has compell'd me, to this duel; ſaid he wou'd brand me, for a coward, if I declin'd it.—What wou'd you have me do?

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Marry his daughter.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: No—Tho' I love her, with the trueſt fondneſs, I will not wed her, upon ſuch terms; nor ſuffer her to think ſo meanly of me, as to ſuppoſe I poorly barter'd a coward's hand, to ſave his worthleſs life.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Yet, conſider, my lord, that let the conſequences of this duel, be what they may, nothing can acquit you of that juſtice, you owe, both to her, and yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: I own that I have greatly wrong'd her.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: It is now within your power, to make reparation, by becoming her huſband; but ſhou'd you deprive her of a father, ſhe never can be united to the man who kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: I will not kill him, Frampton—Urge me, no farther—My mind is torn to pieces.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Believe me, my lord, you are not in a right courſe, to heal it.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: No matter; you have refus'd to be a witneſs of my conduct, Mr. Frampton.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: And do ſo, ſtill: I never had the leaſt reaſon to doubt your bravery; and as this is an affair, in which only principals can be concern'd, I hope it will be no imputation, upon mine, if I decline ſeeing your lordſhip engaged in a ſtrife, where I cannot wiſh you ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: I ſhall not preſs you; but have yet a requeſt to make.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Name it, my lord.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: If I ſhould fall, deliver this letter, to my father; and—if there be any circumſtance of my miſconduct, left untold, which may do Harriet juſtice, inform him of it, fully.—I muſt now go ſeek, for a leſs cautious friend, than Mr. Frampton.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Your lordſhip will ſcarcely ever find a ſincerer. (Exit lord Euſtace.) Of what oppoſite qualities, is this young man compounded? What a mixture, of good, and evil! But are we not all made of the ſame materials? The devil himſelf cannot always miſlead a man, that has principles; they will recur, in ſpite of him, and make their owner act rightly, upon trying occaſions.—This letter to his father, ſhews him to be a man of honor.—Something muſt be done, to preſerve him.—I cannot give him up.—An experiment, tho' a hazardous one, muſt be made, directly.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: When ſhall my tortured mind find reſt! Gracious heaven, preſerve me from diſtraction! Perhaps, in a few moments, my father's ſword may pierce my huſband's heart.—Why has that tender name eſcap'd my lips? Reſentment ſhould have ſtopt its paſſage to my tongue, and ſighs oppoſed its utterance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I don't ſee any harm, child, in your calling him your huſband, tho' to be ſure he is not ſo, in law.—But I wou'd have you hope the beſt, Harriet.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
No, I will hope no more—What ſhou'd I hope?—My pride, my reaſon might have ſcorn'd him, living, but I will love him, and lament him,
dead?—Wou'd I had died, the hour before I liſten'd to your counſel, and ſet at nought, the authority of my father.—Your cruel kindneſs has undone me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I ſhou'd not have thought of meeting ſuch a return, for that kindneſs, from you, Miſs Evans.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Forgive, and pity my diſtraction, madam! 'Tis I that have brought ruin, on ye all—But if you ever loved me, think of ſome means, to find my brother out: he may prevent this duel, and ſave me from the loweſt depth of miſery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Really, child, you are extremely ignorant; you talk as if you were at Mohmouth, where our family are known, and properly reſpected—but in ſuch a place as London, it may poſſibly be as difficult, to find out an Ap Evans, as any of thoſe muſhroom gentry, whoſe Table does not contain above three generations.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My deareſt aunt, do not place bars before my only hope; let all our ſervants be ſent out to ſeek him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Well, child, if it will make you eaſy, they ſhall go, directly; tho' I am of opinion it will be but a fruitleſs inquiry. But the being too eaſily prevail'd upon, is my greateſt foible—I wiſh I had a little of Sir William's obſtinacy, about me.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Conſider, madam, I am on the rack; do not loſe time, I beg of you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p:
Well, be compoſed, I will ſend them; they ſhall ſearch all the genteel coffee-houſes, at the Weſt end of the town—it is impoſſible he ſhou'd be in the city.—But don't let your father know, that I told you of the duel: he thinks women are never to be truſted with any thing; and has no
more reſpect for the empreſs-queen, or the czarina that I have for a county juſtice.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How can ſhe be inſenſible, to griefs like mine!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What, up ſo early, Harriet! Who has diſturbed your reſt?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: O Sir! where is that powerful opiate to be found, that can reſtore it?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: The conſciouſneſs of your own heart, and my forgiveneſs of your only fault, ſhou'd ſet your mind at peace.

sp.speaker: Har..
sp.p: What! while that fault endangers your dear life, and robs my brother of the beſt of fathers?—unworthy as I am to call you by that name.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Her grief almoſt unmans me. (Aſide.)—Why are you agitated thus?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: O do not make my brother hate me, too!—Will he not call me parricide?—or if—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Who has acquainted you, with this affair? I did not think there was a heart ſo brutal.—But do not, Harriet, thus alarm yourſelf—all may be yet repaired.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Never, Sir, never! for here I vow, that ſhou'd lord Euſtace arm his hand, againſt your life, no power on earth, ſhall ever make me his.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Harriet, the laws of honour muſt be ſatisfied; and when I was firſt bleſt, with the fond name of father, yours then became my moſt peculiar care; nor life, nor aught on earth, is half ſo dear to me.—Nay, Harriet, do not weep! I blame you not; your youth, and innocence, have been deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
You are too good, too gentle to me, Sir; I have deſerv'd all the diſtreſs I feel.—Yet hear me,
Sir—If this muſt be—might not my brother, Sir, dear as he is to me—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: My determination cannot now be alter'd: retire, my child.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Captain Loyd, Sir, deſires to ſee your honor.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Shew him up.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Oh, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Leave me, my Harriet, leave me.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: My heart bleeds for her.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I have crouded all the ſail I cou'd make, to come up with you, baronet; and now that I am here, I ſhould be glad to know, in what ſoundings we are, and whether we are to ſteer ſtarboard, or larboard?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: My letter, I believe, captain, muſt have given you to underſtand the reaſon, of my deſiring to ſee you; at preſent, I am unhappily engaged, in a duel, and the opinion I have, both of your bravery, and friendſhip, made me look upon you as the propereſt perſon of my acquaintance, to be my ſecond.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: As to that matter, Sir William, I think, I have diſcharged as many broadſides, as any gentleman in the navy—tho' I never yet drew a trigger, out of the line; but powder and ball, I ſuppoſe, do pretty much the ſame execution, by land, as by ſea; tho' ſtanding fair to the windward, is, ſometimes, of great uſe to us, baronet.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: It is of little conſequence, which way the wind ſits, at preſent, captain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I can't ſay much to that, Sir William.—But I wiſh you had acquainted me with this buſineſs, a day or two ago, I ſhou'd have lik'd to have made a little will—But, 'tis no great matter, neither—For if I ſhould pop over, you daughter's huſband will be my heir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: There is not the leaſt occaſion, for that precaution, captain, as your life will not be endanger'd.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How ſo? When the ſhip is once engaged, muſt not every man aboard her, fight? All but the chaplain, and he ſhou'd be buſy, in his way, too.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: In this caſe, my friend, you need be no farther concern'd, than to ſee that the laws of honor, are not violated.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir William! this may do, for ſome of your freſh water ſparks, but Jerry Loyd will never lie to, when the ſignal's given for chace—no lug-ſail work, for me; I ſhall come pouring down upon them.—But, pray, who is your antagoniſt? And what is the cauſe of your quarrel? Was it a drunken buſineſs?—I was pretty jolly, myſelf, laſt night, but don't remember that I had words, with any one, except the waiter.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I ſhou'd be aſham'd, captain, were I weak enough to run into one vice, from the conſequences of another, or hazard my life, this day, for having been guilty of exceſs, laſt night.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well! if that is not the caſe, I don't know what it is. For I think you are not quarrelſome, when you are ſober.—But have you breakfaſted? Tho' you may have no great appetite, my ſtomach has been ready for a meſs, this half hour, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: We ſhall find every thing prepar'd, in the next room.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Let us make to the ſtore-room, directly; and while we are laying in our proviſions, you may tell me who is your man, and all about it.
sp.stage: Enter Lord EUSTACE, Colonel EVANS, and a Servant.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Let your maſter know, that I am here.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: This is the moſt romantic affair, my lord, that ever I heard of. To ſet out determined to ſtand your enemy's fire, without returning it!

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: The wrongs, I have done him, and his family, ſhou'd be atoned, and not increaſed, colonel; and were it now within my power, I wou'd not take his life, even to ſave my own.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: There I think you are right, my lord; but I can't ſay I ſhou'd carry-my politeneſs, ſo far, as to make him a compliment, of mine.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: There is ſomething much higher than politeneſs, in the queſtion, at preſent—juſtice, colonel—A man may diſpenſe with the one, but not the other.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am intirely of your opinion; but as your ſentiments are ſo very delicate, and that you really love the girl, why may not I, as your ſecond, ſtep in, and ſave the exploſion of gunpowder, and the lady's character, by preventing the duel?

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: I will not ſuffer it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: As you intend to offer her your hand, when this buſineſs is over, I don't ſee why you ſhou'd run the hazard, of loſing life or limb; and if the father be a man of honor, as you ſay he is, I ſhou'd think—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I will not be reſtrained! No, I will ruſh between their cruel ſwords!
sp.stage: Enter, at the ſame Inſtant, at oppoſite Doors, Sir WILLIAM, and HARRIET.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My brother, here! then heaven has heard my prayer.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: My ſon!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Will you not ſpeak to me?
sp.stage: (To the Col. who turns from her.)

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Are you her brother?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Yes, I have that diſhonour—Ill fated girl!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What can this mean? Are you come hither, to abet the man, who has diſgraced your ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My father can't ſuppoſe it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Retire, this moment, then, and take her with you—My lord, I am ready to attend you, ſingly.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You ſhall not go, for I will cling, for ever, here.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: I cannot bear this ſight—Pray hear me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Take her away. (To the Col.) This is no time for expoſtulation—Come, my lord—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nay then, Sir, I muſt interfere—I cannot ſuffer you to turn aſſaſſin, even for her—Lord Euſtace has not charg'd his piſtols, nor does he mean to raiſe his arm againſt you—You cannot take his life, upon theſe terms.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Does he deſpiſe me, then?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: A little gleam of hope, breaks in upon me.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Your ſon can anſwer that, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: With truth, my lord, I ſay you do not—Now, you muſt anſwer me.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Your being perfectly acquainted with my intentions, towards your ſiſter, before I knew that you were related to her, ſhou'd, I think, be a ſufficient anſwer, to any demand you can poſſibly have to make.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: By no means, my lord; tho' your tenderneſs for the weakneſs you have cauſed, may incline you to repair her loſt honor, I muſt and will, be guardian of my own; and nothing but your meeting me, on fair and equal terms, can heal the wound you have given it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Now, Harry, you are my ſon.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Inhuman brother! will nothing, but his life, content your rage? Let me die for him.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: My angel Harriet!—But ſince it muſt be ſo, I am ready, colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I hope your lordſhip thinks I ſtand acquitted of my obligations to you, by preventing your engaging, on ſuch unequal terms, for that unworthy girl.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: You wrong her much; it is I alone am guilty.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: It is true, my ſon; Harriet is innocent.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: If that be true, I have a double right to vengeance!

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: You have a right to chuſe your reparation, Sir, and I attend you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: When ſhall my miſeries end!
sp.stage: As Lord EUSTACE, and Col. EVANS, are going off, Enter Mr. FRAMPTON.

sp.speaker: Framp.
sp.p: I hope, this moment, madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Frampton!

sp.speaker: Framp.
sp.p:
I have no ſort of buſineſs, with your lordſhip,
my commiſſion is directed to Sir William Evans, and lady Euſtace.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Do not inſult me, Sir; I am not lady Euſtace.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Nor ever ſhall be.

sp.speaker: Framp.
sp.p: That is a point, that will not, I think, admit of being conteſted.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You are miſtaken, Sir; but this is trifling.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: I am on the rack—explain yourſelf, my friend.

sp.speaker: Framp.
sp.p: You muſt give me leave to ſpeak, then—When I ſaw the diſtreſs, and anxiety of your mind, I was fully ſatisfied of your honourable intentions, towards this lady, from the letter you entruſted me with, which yet remains unopened.—I determin'd, if poſſible, to preſerve both your life, and honour, for her ſake, by preventing your duel, with her father, and your marriage, with lady Anne Mountfort.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: The firſt event, Sir, has been prevented, without your aſſiſtance, and I will venture to promiſe, that the ſecond ſhall never take place.

sp.speaker: Framp.
sp.p: I am quite of your opinion, Sir. As I came, this moment from lord Delville, to acknowledge this fair lady, as his ſon's wife—but this letter Sir William, will more fully explain his lordſhip's ſentiments.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: My generous friend! my guardian angel!

sp.speaker: Framp.
sp.p: My lord, I neither deſire, nor deſerve, your thanks.—If I have been, in any way, ſerviceable to you, attribute it to my real attachment, to your truly amiable wife.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I do not underſtand all this.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: 'Tis as I gueſs'd, exactly.—All ſmoke, and no fire.—My nephew, here! Then ſomething may be done—I rejoice to ſee you, Harry.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Lord Delville has behav'd, like a man of honour; but yet I muſt inform you, Sir, that the generoſity of his conduct, cannot efface the baſeneſs of his ſon—My daughter ſhall never be his wife—He has diſgrac'd her.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Never, Sir! Here is my witneſs—this letter, which I now entreat my Harriet to peruſe, will fully prove, that had I fallen by your hand, her honour wou'd have been preſerv'd.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I will not read it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I think that was behaving like a man of quality.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Let me entreat you, Sir William, to look it over, as I can, with truth and honour, atteſt the ſincerity of the writer.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: There need no farther vouchers. Let Harriet now determine, for herſelf.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: The ſtruggle is too great.—I cannot ſpeak—Leave me, my lord—

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Never, whilſt I have life, will I forſake you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: It cannot be, my lord—Tho' I have the higheſt ſenſe of gratitude, for lord Delville's goodneſs to me, and tho' I believe you perfectly ſincere, in what you ſay, at preſent; yet the humiliating ſituation, into which you have plunged me, the diſtreſs you have brought upon my family, your attachment to another lady——

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: With ſhame I muſt confeſs my trifling with a lady, whom I cou'd not have lov'd, even had my Harriet been unknown to me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I think I may venture to aſſure your lordſhip, that lady Anne Mountfort will be very ready to forgive your want of paſſion for her, as her partiality for me, might, perhaps, have been the cauſe of her blindneſs, to your ſuperior merits.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: I congratulate your good fortune, colonel; and am indebted to your generoſity, for removing every ſhadow of difficulty, on lady Anne's account.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Nephew, I wiſh you joy—There will be one wom of quality, at leaſt, in the family.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Weak as I am, my lord, you cannot ſhake my reſolution

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: I have no hope, but in your interpoſition, Sir: you are her father, and have been moſt offended; yet you, perhaps, have the goodneſs to forgive!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Aye, and give, too, my lord; the man who ſincerely repents of error, is farther remov'd from vice, than one who has ne'er been guilty—This letter is a ſufficient, and convincing proof, of your contrition. Take her; ſhe is, and ſhall be yours.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: My wife!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: The commands of a father, muſt not be reſiſted—O! my lord, how different are my preſent ſenſations, from thoſe I ſuſtained, when I ventur'd to beſtow this hand, without his ſanction!—But take it; it is yours, for ever, now.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p: Then every wiſh of my fond heart is accompliſhed.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Joy to your lordſhip, and my deareſt Harriet!

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: I ſincerely wiſh your ladyſhip all the happineſs, which I well know you have deſerv'd.

sp.speaker: Ld Euſt.
sp.p:
And you, my friend, ſhall ſhare it with us, who have ſteer'd my courſe to this bleſt harbour, thro' all the ſhoals and quick-ſands of my folly.
—You ſhall be happy, too, if ought within my fortune, or my power, can render you ſo.

sp.speaker: Fram.
sp.p: Continue to preſerve your preſent bliſs, my lord, and I am over-paid.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: I think I have a right to partake, in your ladyſhip's felicity, from the principal ſhare I have had, in bringing this event to paſs. I hope that lord Delville has been properly inform'd—
—That man is my perpetual torment.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why, hey-day, Sir William! What wind's a blowing, now? You ſeem to have caſt anchor, when I thought you were putting out to ſea.—Here is the whole crew aſſembled; Miſs Winifred, and all.—Do women fight duels? If I had them on board the Dreadnought, I'd clap them all under hatches, before ſhe engaged.—But come along, baronet, you don't mean to ſlack ſail, now, I hope—I thought, by this time, we ſhou'd have made a few eyelet holes, in the enemy's rigging.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I hope, my good friend, you will excuſe my ſeeming inattention, to your impatient bravery, when I tell you, that our conteſt has ended happily, and that you may now wiſh all this company, as well as lord Euſtace, joy.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: He is to be married, then, it ſeems—I hope, madam, you'll believe me, another time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Win.
sp.p: Yes, when you tell truth, captain—But, at preſent, you happen to be a little out, in your ſoundings, for the ſhip's name is not the lady Anne, but the lovely Harriet—The country girl, you talked of.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Well, well, all is one to me.—So ſhe is bound for the port of matrimony, I am content—
and ſo I wiſh your lordſhip, your ladyſhip, and all your ſhips, a proſperous voyage, to the iſland of happineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.l: They promiſe fair, to reach that wiſh'd-for port:
For virtue, tho' of winds and waves the ſport,
By paſſions ſhaken, and by danger croſt,
On life's great ſea, is never wholly loſt.
Some power divine conducts her ſwelling ſails,
And, of her due reward, ſhe ſeldom fails.

div.head: EPILOGUE, Written by the Author of the PROLOGUE, And Spoken by Mrs. CLIVE.
div.l: I LONG to know, dread Sirs, with due ſubmiſſion,
How you approve me, as a politician?
The thought was mine.—I told the ſcrib'ling dame,
This part of Winifred, is much too tame;
Aſk but the town, ſaid I, they'll all agree,
That a tame character, will not ſuit me:
I hate ſuch lifeleſs, water-gruel ſtuff;
Quicken her well, with politicks, and ſnuff:
Small quantities of both, will be but teizing;
Give them enough, and ſet the town a ſneezing.
Her ſcribbling vanity at this was ſtung;
Would have diſputed—Hold, ſays I, you're wrong,
Don't be ſo raſh, to draw on me, your tongue;
I have a weapon, ſhould I take the field,

l.hi: A better, never did a woman wield;

div.l: You'll find, when once my paſſion is afloat,
The ſoul of Caeſar, in a petticoat!
"Aye, but," ſays ſhe, "in politicks there's danger,
"To courts, and ſtate affairs, I'm quite a ſtranger."
So much the better, thou moſt ſimple woman,
Blunders, in politicks, are not uncommon.
When you miſtake, the town will think you clever,
Think that you mean great folks, and clap, for ever;
Old England, like a boy, loves wicked fun,
Abuſe your betters, and your work is done.
Small game the Engliſh ſpirit will not follow,
'Tis at the nobler chace, you whoop, and hollow!
O'er hedge, and ditch, you helter ſkelter fly.
Start but a ſtateſman—Yoax! the hounds full cry!
To pick up leſſer game, you will not ſtay,
While the fox runs, the hare may ſteal away;
Our auth'reſs is the hare—who trembling ſits,
'Till ſhe eſcapes this dreadful pack of wits;
She hopes you will not hunt her, ſhe's ſo ſmall,
But hark to mercy, as the nobleſt call.

div.head: AN EPILOGUE, Written by HENRY JAMES PYE, Eſq

lg.l: WELL! after much perplexity and rout,
At length the wiſhed-for wedding's brought about.
A fooliſh girl! ſo near to throw away
Love, rank, and reputation, in a day.
And all for what? from prejudice, in truth,
Tho' chriſtened delicacy, now, forſooth.
If (ſentimental nonſenſe thrown aſide)
To cards, and politics, ſhe had applied,
For common cares, her ſoul had been too great,
And only felt an ardor, for the ſtate;
Had glow'd alone with freedom's glorious flame,
And next to PAM's, had honour'd PAOLI's name.
Twice in our annals, baffled France and Spain
Have wept the glories of a female reign:
With great ſucceſs I think we now might try
The influence of a female miniſtry.
In private life how well we're uſed to ſway,
More huſbands know, than you'll perſuade to ſay;
And how finances properly to rule,
All ladies learn, who ever kept a pool.
Ye generous ſpirits, who approve my plan,
And wiſh at leaſt an equal ſway with man,
(And ſome malicious wits ſo bold we find,
To ſay this comprehends all woman-kind)
In favour of a female bard, to-night,
Boldly aſſert a Briton's deareſt right;
From man, from haughty man's tyrannic laws,
To your deciſion ſhe ſubmits her cauſe;
Reſts, on your candor, all her hopes and fears,
And only claims—a Trial by her Peers.
